message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change (in kJ/mol) for the following chemical reaction at 298 K:
2SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2SO3(g)
Given the standard enthalpies of formation (∆Hf°) at 298 K for SO2(g), O2(g), and SO3(g) are -296.8 kJ/mol, 0 kJ/mol, and -396.0 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the given reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given reaction, we have:

ΔH° = [2 × ΔHf°(SO3) - (2 × ΔHf°(SO2) + ΔHf°(O2))]

Now, we can plug in the given values for the standard enthalpies of formation:

ΔH° = [2 × (-396.0 kJ/mol) - (2 × (-296.8 kJ/mol) + 0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = [-792.0 kJ/mol - (-593.6 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = -198.4 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the given reaction at 298 K is -198.4 kJ/mol.
